title: 106_hr4744
content: The Act may be cited as the "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000". It includes findings and purposes. The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions and promote effective congressional oversight to ensure proper implementation of laws by the executive branch. Congress recognizes the need for accurate information to make informed decisions and address uncontrolled regulatory costs. The "Truth in Regulating Act of 2000" aims to increase transparency in regulatory decisions, promote effective congressional oversight, and enhance accountability of Congress and agencies to the people they serve. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. In this Act, "agency" refers to the definition in section 551(1) of title 5, United States Code. "Economically significant rule" includes any proposed or final rule with a significant economic impact or affecting various aspects. "Independent evaluation" involves a substantive review of data and methodology used in developing economically significant rules. The Comptroller General will conduct an independent evaluation of the agency's data, methodology, and assumptions used in developing economically significant rules. This evaluation will include an explanation of how strengths or weaknesses in the data support or detract from the agency's conclusions, as well as the implications of these strengths or weaknesses for the rulemaking. The Comptroller General will evaluate the agency's data, methodology, and assumptions for economically significant rules, analyzing strengths and weaknesses and their implications for rulemaking. When an agency publishes an economically significant rule, a committee member can request the Comptroller General to review it. The Comptroller General will submit a report on the rule to the relevant committees within a specified timeframe. The Comptroller General will conduct an independent evaluation of economically significant rules upon request by a committee member. The evaluation will assess the potential benefits and costs of the rule, including effects that cannot be quantified in monetary terms. The evaluation of economically significant rules includes assessing potential benefits and costs, identifying persons or entities likely to bear costs, evaluating alternative approaches, summarizing regulatory impact analysis, and implications of the evaluation by the Comptroller General. The Comptroller General will develop procedures for prioritizing requests for review of proposed and interim final rules, giving highest priority to requests regarding notice of proposed rulemaking. The procedures prioritize requests for review of proposed and interim final rules, giving highest priority to requests regarding notice of proposed rulemaking. Each agency must cooperate promptly with the Comptroller General in carrying out the Act. Authorization of appropriations for the General Accounting Office is set at $5,200,000 annually for fiscal years 2001 through 2003. The Act will take effect 180 days after enactment and will not apply to rules published three years after the effective date.
